seems to b© correct. We must also bear in mind that part of the refugees fled "westwards over the others Dniester and th© Zbruch, and ax again {possibly several hundreds) arrived in Constantinople as oceasidkial passengers on different ship3„ Those who fled over the rivers were apparently numerous: thousands of Jews in Roumania, Ukrainians , and so on. P»53s According to th© emigration press published in the years 1921-22, nearly all the repatriated refugees were executed soon after their return to Soviet Russia. Of course there was very little truth in these re orts. Unforutnafcely it is imp&ssibl© to trace in th© Soviet press any indi¬ cation about the fate of those who returned to * their country. It may be we could learn th© '//here¬ abouts of individuals from private letters and personal accounts J but these sources are not always reliable and cannot prove much. countries. The designation "cavalry" and "infantry" are here only nominal♦ The±u headquarters continued to cmsider the army as if the War was still going on, and strictly concealed from the pubic all information about the number of transported sold44rs» 2*.35: The anti-Bolshevist headquarters had of course at thai'time no agreement whatever with the Soviet government about the r patriation of their troops. I don't know what kind of arrangement was made by the French under whose protection the camps were administered, ^he order given by General Brussot at the end of January 1321 emphasised the necesslty"for the sake of the Russians of sup orting as far a s possible the re-evacuation In accordance with the decision taken irrevocably by the refugees who wanted to return to their homeland". p,57« Unfortunately it is quite impossible to compile a table about the evacuation from Constantinople of those 35.000 whc remained there on 1st January 1922. We still miss the necessary documents. I myself went throu^i much of the available material but nevertheless I am not in a position to compile such a table. The majority 0 had already left for other countries, with the help of relatives and friends who sent them the necessary travel documents and visas. At the best/

best we could i. ix only the main routes taken by the refugees. But these are evident from the general picture of their later distribution. P-tiii The figure of 30,000 interned troops is not quite comprehensible to me. If you have in mind, the Heel soldiers I can neither confirm nor reject this figure as I have no information on this point. The majority of than were allowed to return to Soviet Russia, P.«87: The answer to this query about Roumania you will find in the first part of this report. P*55: *he answer can be partly found again In the first part of my re ort. I beliww© that the figures of Russian refugees in Germa y in 192$ must have been nearly twice as high as those for 1925. This was quite evident from the everyday life of the Russian emigration in Germany. Many of the Russian commercial undertakings in Germany had to be liquidated. The Russian Scientific Institute had to discontinue its activities not only on account of lack of means but also owing to the decreasing number of students. The main wave of the emigration left for France and the trans-Atlantic countries. Some of the refugees acquired German citizenship. The figures of the German census might be correct for 1925, but they do not contradict the number of 250,0t)0 for 1922. If one wishes to be careful it must b© admitted that/

that for the beginning of 1322 there were about 175,000 ref-ogees but at the end of the same year their number must have been considerably higher. We are unable to get official figures for Czechoslovakia for 192$ # It Is even dudbtful if such statistical data have ever been collected# The number of 20,000 for the beginning of 1922 might be extremely exaggerated, but for the end of the year it migftt be quite correct. Besides the organised evacuations of students and Cossacks from Bizerta and Constantinople to Prague we must not overlook those students who risked coming to Prague on their own Initiative without visa or money. Therefore there could not be any exact statistics. For 1923, when Czechoslovakia had her highest number of refug >es, two figures are us willy quoted: 22,000 and 30,000. It is possible that this difference was caused by the Ukrainians who entered Carpatho-Russla from Poland# Since 1924 the number of refugees in Uzechos\ovakia has continually decreased# Those who to k their degr-es left for the colonies. At present the number of refugees does not exceed 7,000 and might be efeen less. p#56; The answer has already been given# p»50: I don't think that a general rule could be established# The Jews usually approached their own special organisations as these had larger sums at their disposal. But Jewish organ¬ isations )uuix±» h i ped in many cases also non- Jewish,/

Jewish Russian refugees. In their turn the c la ins of the Je?/s for support were not rejected by the Russian organisations. The Russian Jews were included in the general statistics of the Russian organisations, but as time went on the Russian Jews isolated the,:selves, being more and mo ;e supported by their co-religionists in those countries where they settled down. The shortness of time does not permit me to give a more detailed answer to your questions. Dispersion In the Far Bast. Finally I will try to teasm. give yen some information about the emigration from Siberia* The conditions there were even more complicated than in Europe as the civil war in Siberia lasted longer than in the south of Russia, and the tendency to move toe Harfein ( at that time in fact a Russian town) became apparent as long ago as 1917. Many military persons who used to serve in the frontier guard of the trans-Amur district gathered in Harbin# There were also those who previously kept up some business connections with the Far Bast, The first refugees came from Kazan in September 1913 and, with the continuous defeat of the Siberian armies they were driven farther and farther eastward. Many unknown graves still mark this long march of their retreat. The Volga and Kama/

Kama formations - the "Votkin & Izhevsky" divisions which later on joined tho army of Kajpsl remained or the front up to the end as they had no where to escape. Different At&mena and refugee groups went to the south and crossed in several points the Chinese frontier. The state frontier of the former Russian Empire has been passed by single inoMvidu Is as well as by whole groups from the eastern shores of the Caspian sea up to Vladivostok. I would like to point out that the majority of the Ural Cossacks and the Caspian seamen from the Mesopotarais camp Basra were brou-ht to Vladivostok. I can present here only some figures from the Far East leaving out the numerous evacuations of different groups as for Instance of Baron Ungern, K&sagrand!f Bakych, Snnenkov, Belov, Dutov and many others. All the figures would be approximate! as no statistics were taken at the time, "he estimate of the crossing of the frontiers to Persia, Hast Turk!stan, Mongolia and Manchuria < t later periods can also nofc be firmly established. The total of the emigration to Asia, a considerable part of which went at a very early date to America, Australia and other places, has been just as "ftt European emigration often exaggerated. I foun : such figures as even of half a million but generally the total Is presented as 200 - 250,000. I suppose that even these figures are/

exaggerated to a very large extent. I believe that the emigration over the Asiatic frontiers did not exceed 130 - 160,000, I shall in future give only figures which are more or leas reliable. According to the report of Kyrllov presented in 1921 to the Zemgor after the collapse of the "olchak government the emigration from Siberia proceeded C; ) in few ifferent directions. Firstly, about 40 to 45,000 went to the east together v^ith the retreating Czechoslovaks. Not more than 30,0"0 reached the eastern Chinese railway. Secondly, fchete* crmbatents of General Eappel retreated in Novemb r 1920 to .'.an churl a an afterwards to the Pacific Coast (Eyrilov supposed them to be together with their famines about 60,000); thirdly, refugees to Mongolia which number is not indicated by Kyrilov. I think that all these figures are somehow exaggerated. In the !&eath trains" perished more persons than Kyrilov assumed. At the counting ©£- in Ch&ta in March 1920 all the three Siberian armies and cavalry formations were registered as 25,000 soldiers. f-he Id organisation of the He-" Cross rave in their report (published in Harbin 1323) for the end of 1921 already some lower figures, namely 30,000 (about 20,000 at the Chinese Eastern Railway about 6,000 in China, East Turkistan and Mongolia and about 4,000 on the Pacific coast. The military formations which were at that time still fighting at the front are apparently not included in this figure. On 1 January 1922 the Hussian emigration in Europe had become more or less stabilised. At the same time in the remotest corner of the former Hussian empire

Russian empire the last milifcayy fighting was * left still continuing. Vladivostok was eyaeM»*jed by General ) icierichs on 20 October 1322 and on 24 October the warships of the Siberian flotilla of Admiral Stark went away from the harbour. These dates nearly two years later than the frrangel evacuation indicate the end of the Civil War in the Far East. We possess exact figures about the military contingent of General Diderich's troops for the 1 October 1922, It means 3 weeks before the evacuation of Vladivostok; soldiers Volga group (of Gen.Molchanov) 647 officers & 2,720/ Siberian Tf (" " Smolin) 583 rl " 1,923 " Small different 1,038 " 4,116 Tf groups gunners Siberian flotilla and the 541 t! 1,635 " Totals 2,009 10,394 to this mo in mass of 13,205 soldiers the majority of which left the last pert of their homeland, must be added a certain number of women and chil ran who had to share their exile. The troops of General Gmolln Increased toj- ther with women and children to 3,000 persons retreated to the district of Pogranlchnoye. The great majority of these people were later on scattered over the whole of Manchuria• The group of General Molchanov and other smsll groups went alonr the westorn coast of the nmur *^ay towards PossyattIn addition to those a part of the slfek and wounded were c rried by ship to the some place• Another part was at once directed to the Korean/

Korean port of Gens an. ™hese two places Possyat and Gensan fulfilled fcheip- thereby the same role for the emigration of the Far East as Constantinople in the west* In Possyat were about concentrated/9,000 refugees, 5,200 people consist¬ ing mainly of sick women and children were evacuated through the Chinese border station in Hun-Chun to Guirin. The military formations were also brought to Guinin.fln the 1 January 1923 the Gulnin camp counted chlIdren Of the Volga-Kama group 3,036 soldiers, 208 women & 140 / Other small groups 4,499 w 445 n 515 " Total 7,535 653 461 The c evelopment of the Guirin camp from February to October was very similar to that which took place In Constantinople, A small number were repatriated to Russia, another part went to America, others again dispersed over Manchuria and China, In Gensan remained about 5,500 persons including those who disembarked there from different ships. T'hey stayed in Corea until the spring of 1923 and afterwards were also scattered over China* In Gensan were further concentrated 15 war ships from the flotilla of Admiral Stark# On board those ships were navy men with their families, several groups of army men and the remnants of the Kadets corps e£ from Omsk and Khabarovsk. Alto-I gh&her were on these ships about 2,000 seamen and I approximately the same number of civilians. Japanese did not agree to admit them into Gensan and the vessels were compelled to depart for Shanghai % a where a considerable part of the refugees were allowed to disembark and succeeded In settling down*

The rest of about 2,000 persons landed in Manila Bay from where they a ailed tc the Philippines, t& America and Australia, Probably half of the Russian refugees staying at present in Australia we drawn from those Siberian refugees. The Ataman Tolstov with his group of Ural Cossacks is for instance also there, On the way to Shanghai the ship "Lieutenant Dydymov" was wrecked by a storm and h©-b& none of the passengers could be rescued. The steamer "Ayaxn was also destroyed on its way to -Manila and only a few parsons could be saved. We can therefore conclude that after the final breakdown of the anti-Bolshevist movement so as to speak the seealie# tregistered^migratropin the Far Ea^t consisted of 21,149 persons* According to the information given by the Red Cross at the end of 1921 30,000 refugees were :.n the Far Hast .together with the newcomers there 'fijuj S~ 0, must have been a little more. This figure correspon / / with the estimate of the Red Cross which counted at the end of 1322 the general number of refugees as 3:50,000. The following groups of refugees were mentioned in the re port:- In the Khailar-M&nchuria district abt, 18,000 " " Harbin " " 7,000 " different points alon^ the eastern and western lines of the Chinese Eastern Ra llways about 2,000 n the districts around the towns of Huhg-Chung, Guirin, and Chang- Chung abouto, 11,000 chiefly composed of the remnants of General Dietrich rs army and thei families In Gensan, ( the Korean port)S 5,000 In different Chinese ^owns (Moukden, Tiantsin, Shanghai etc, abt, 3,000 In East Turkestan and Mongolia abt. 4,000 belonging to the retreat fcing Kolchak troops.

These figures are obviously underestimated, firstly the Hed Cross itself eemmeHee mentions that these statistics do not include refugees who possess a more or less normal income or who saved some means and therefore do not need any phlianthropi help. Secondly, they do not Iraelttde comprise those persons who left with flotilla of Admiral Stark, In fact the real number of refugees in the Far East for the end of 1922 was higher, approximately 60 to 70,000. At that time different military formations still continued their guerilla fight along the whole Asiatic frontier and undoubtably at the end of the next year the total of refugees and interned persons increased by not less than 20,000. Therefore at the end of 1923 in Asia could be counted 80 to 90,000 refugees, ke :<t in mind It must be further the individual crossings of different frontiers which at one time were very considerable. If we would multiply by two the number of refugees we should come to a figure of 160 to ISO,COG as a result of the civil war in Asia. I myself am inclined tc reduce this figure and I suppose that [ there ere no more than 130 to 160,000 persons. I 2O.May, 1938.

essay:div.essay:p: SPn.AKY Of THIS rS. yX.V. HE ;SBN. - February 1938. I. - IN FIHMND. In Relsingfors Hessen was struck by the unreal atmosphere in which the Russian refugees were living, and, by the quick changes which the Revolution has brought about in their psychology and their point of views. Kusmin-Karavaev, a former member of the second "Duma" had changed his liberal opinioiB to right ones, and had moreover become an anti-se aite. m . , _ /in Heisinrfors To axs influence was due - lie for mation'of the "Political Centre" centred around General U&enieh, and composed of Gen. Udenich, Kartashev, Kusrain-Karavaes and the oil- agnate 8.G. Lianosov, and two more generals, Those who -were not included in the Council felt offended; among them was lies sen himself. The creation of the "Political Centre" had several results: 1) it facilitated the putting into circulation of one of the fictions of that time - the paper money. The author had met later a young man who had collected about 8,OCO different specimens of civil war money. Description of this money. On the North Western front several atte pts had been made to solve the question of money. Gen. Rodzianko published"the army money" for JO million roubles without any backing. It was finally decided to order money to be printed in Stockholm, the -uarantee was the promise to pay back rouble for rouble as soon as Petersburg will be taken by Gen. Udenich. But this money was not circulated* 2) The "Political Centre" represented an organ to which Finland and Estonia now applied for the recognition of their new independence; and this recognition was a condition /anti-bolshevist. organizations for the refugee?!'to stay on the territory of these countries. On the other hand the "Political Council" itself stood in need of the recognition by General Kolchak and by the Council of Ambassadors( which detained the available funds); the attitude / of both Gen. Kolchak and the Ambassadors Council towards the "Political Centre" was reserved. 0^*" j -V* ./ (j)

The refugees firmaly believed in their victory over the Bolsheviks, even the crushing down of the Cronstadt rebellion did not discourage them, on the contrary, it gave to them the assurance that the population was with them, end that action was necessary. The most active representative of this belief was ,3, F'argulless. On his arrival from the South of Rusria in Finland he or-anized lectures, meetings, etc. Through the correspondent of "The Times" in Finland, .Polak he entered into connection with the English generals: Gen. Roff and Gen I, arsh. The result was that at the beginning of August on a gesture of Gen. ;arsh the 1 orth "astern Government was created, literally in two days. Ressen describes the intrigues ad quarrels which arose among those Russian <Sniigrds who were called to form the Government„ The situation was fantastic and impossible to understand. The birth of the North-Eastern Government raised great effervescence among the Russian 4migr6s in Helsingfors. The failures of Gen. Udenich resulted in the Estonian authorities growing inpatient of the presence of the North estern Government on their territory and in their asking Gen. Kolchak to recognize their independence. The Helsingfors authorities also became nervous and the general effervescence was still increased by the arrival of wandering generalsi who having failed in the South of .Russia came to Finland in search of new possibilities. Then came the sudden success of Gen. Udenich who succeeded in occupying Sarskoe Solo; refugees from Finland went to see their relations in Zarskoe Selo. The .'North /estern Government grew anxious for Gen. Udenich did not intend to keep it. Hess en also visited "'arskoe Salo to ?e© his grand¬ child. ^Reflections on the new generation for whom famine had become the fundamental fact of existence. Doubts as to whether they wouldneed the ideas of the old generation.

The brief success of Udenich1s army was followed by a complete disaster. The Estonian Government entered into negotiations with the Soviet Government, The Russian generals accused one another. The allied missions remained indifferent. At la st Gen. Balachovich arrested Gen. Ud@ni.ch and compelled the latter to restore the funds which were still in his possession Gen. Udenich went to the South of France where he started a poultry farm. As to the ragged and f and shed North Vest em army it arrived at Narva where it was stopped by the Estonian barjbed wire barrier. In the meantime the Premier of the .Worth Western Government, which at that time was already expelled from Reval, continued to assure the Estonia: Government that the Russian North Western army was in good condition and that the Government were planning a new ua. paign in alliance with Estonia and Finland and with the assistance of the allies. All this seems absolutely fantastic but so is the announcement in one of the emigre papers in Paris dated 26th March 1937- "To-day in the Hall of the HMOS (26, Av. de Tokio) the Union of the Members of the N.-W. army of C-en, Udenich is organizing an artistic evening. Ranees until morning."

II. Journey to Germany, The tragic end of the Korth astern Array put before the refuges the question what to do further. The hope for the fall of the Soviet Government was not yet dead, but the time of tnis event seamed to have become more remote. The caiup life had to be replaced by a more stable one though still provisional. Owing to the change of the attitude of Finland the question arose as to where to go# It was impossible to stay there any longer# Hessen aid not think that it was possible for him, former publisher of the newspaper "Rech" pBech* had insisted on the continuation of the war with the Germans until a victorious end) to go to Germany# But he was invited-to Berlin by the large publishing firm Ullstein with a view to negotiating the organization of the publishing of Russian books. %oney could be easily raised among the Russian-, for aany of them wished to invest their capitals which they had succeeded in bringing with t em to foreign countries. Without any difficulty 20,000 gold, dollars were gathered for the organisation of a Russian publishing firm. The attitude of the Germans towards the refugejs was at that time very sympathetic. The ruined Germany had no inclination to remind they refugees of their position. Description of the state in which Germany was at that time. In Berlin Hessen .et the publishers of the two most important German newspapers, Dr. olf from the "Berliner Tageblatt" and Prof. Bernhard from the •'Vosstsche 'eitung". Both are now refugees in Paris. Hessun gave an interview to one of the collaborators of the "Berliner Tageblatt" end an article of his dealing also with the Russian affairs was published in the "Yossisohe "eitung"♦ An official from the Russian Department at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs offered to Hessen his assistance for the organization of the Russian publishing firm. Hessen wrote an article for the

"I\Tew Russia" a Journal published by P.Milioukov, who at that time was living in London* The Russian ©migration in Germany( apart from the prisoners of war who gradually appeared from the concentra- tion-caips) was not -very numerous at that time. Neither was it organised# There was only one beneficient Society:"The Society for the assistance of Russian citizens of 1916" which was formed et the beginning of the war and which now began to apply its activity to the refugees from the Soviet Russia. There also was at that time a gr up of persons organized by the advocate V.B. ^tankevlchf this group was the precursor ' ' \ of the pro-Soviet movement in the emigration. Describes the composition of this group# Brief discussion of Stankevichds book "'.'to rid and ork" # Description of the Ullstein firm and its history# Charac5 eristic of its Director Dr. Craven- stein# Notes the interest of the firm in Russia and the possibilities of commercial relations with it. A contract was.concluded by Hessen with,the Ullstein firm for the creation of a Russian publishing firm. lies sen went back to Finland, where his wife and the wife of A.Eaminka.tried to bring from Russia through the help of t e Finish peasants,Yrtio made it their business to help smuggling people over the frontier from Russia, their sons. The refugees in Helsingfors were quieted down and the majority of them had aire dy begun the hard struggle for life, the most important personalities among the Russians had left Finland# Tells of his activities to help the refugees in various matters# In V the meantime his children, two sons and. a grand1 daughter were \ "s struggled in to Finland# Rep-Oits the tragic case of Prof# Nolde shot by the Finish patrol through mistake whilst he was crossing the frontier in order to escape from Russia.

III, - Settled Life. Hessen returned to Berlin, during his absence the number of Russian refugees had increased. The impression from them was that of something like a "state in a state11. It soon became evident that in spite of the friendliness shown by the Germans there was an antagonism between them and the Russian refugees. On one hand the saving spirit of the Germans was ci.istast.ful to the Russians, on the other hand Russian habits of getting to bed very late and disucssing their affairs during the night made them && very inconvenient tenants. Great shortage of flats in Berlin. Large practice of bribery. The Ullstein firm had even a special man employed for the purpose of bribing the officials. ascription of this anonymous person and his technique• Through this man Her sen succeeded in finding a flat for his family. Description of the flat. Botes the frequent marriages between the German aristocrats and rich Jewish girls; thinks that this was due to the high degree of assimilation reached by the Jews in Germany. Description of the new life which now began* people who used to visit his house, the artist Olga Gzovska and VI. Gaidarov, the tour of the Kussian .jrt Theatre, which later on returned to Russia with the exception of a few artists. Relates two dinners given in the honour of the artists. Notes a speech made by the artist Podgorny who spteke with irritation against the emigration. Hessan could not help feeling that there was something degrading in the work "refugee" which implied unfaithfulnes to Russia. A feeling shared by had/ many refugees. Keports tnat the Russian Polpred ftrestinsky twice expressed the desire of the Soviet Government to have Hessen back in Russia in order to produce an impression in Europe and heighten their prestige. ith the Germans there was no true contact and after the first time of exitement and interest on their part as to the

adventures of the Russian refugees the relations became formal. Describes the difficulties to find another flat in which he succeeded* ihis flat became the centre of oil sorts of meetings of refugees who were continually creating new organisations and Unions# specially notes the usefulness of the Union of the Russian Jews headed by J.L. Teitl (now dead) and their beneficient activity which was extended in «• any cases to Christians. A very characteristic process was the desintegration of the former Russian political parties, which still continued to exist in the emigration, they now began to divide into numerous factions which all had different opinions. "The Party of the Popular Liberty (K-D. Party - Hessen, Milioukov) underwent the same process. K-D groups having very little in co son with one another were formed in Belgrade, Prague, Sofia etc. In Peris such a group headed by T'ilioukov acquired also a new name:"The Democratic Group of the Party of the Popu¬ lar Liberty". Hassen thought that it was neces; ary to dissolve the Party, but other members of the Party were against it, though they all agreed that the Party did not exist any more. The reasons for such an attitude are very difficult to understand, in any ease all the parties as well as the individuals were struggling for influence as representatives of the emigration. This ambition was also shared by the beneficient institutions. Hessen was elected Chairman of the "American Fund" a society for the distribution to the refugee intellectuals of help from Americans, 'ho at that time were enjoying a period of prosperity and were interested in Russian refugees. Owing to the inflation this worls was very difficult. Hessen insisted that the rembers of the "American Fund" should receive no help from the Fund. ith the exception of one incident this principle was observed during all the time of the existence of the "American Fund", which lasted more than 13 years. It was liquidated by Hitler.

(Here Hessen makes a digression and says that since the establishment of the Hitler regime the anti-oemitism has much increased among the Russian refugees in Germany) Matters stood differently in the "Union cf the Hussion Journalists and Writers in Germa^**, where lessen also was elected Chairman. The "union" organized meetings lectures,etc, which had a great success both with the Russians and the Germans. The fir ft of these .isetings v/as devoted to Dostoevski. Remarks that the jewels worn by the Russian ladies provoked the irritation of the Germans, and one of the important German officials pointed it out to the representatives of the Union. Difficulty of organising social evenings especi¬ ally when there was an artistic programme, due to the necessity of sparing the sensibility of the artists. Remarks that already in ViaeheSlav Ivanov,a well-known Russian poet, pointed out the "crisis of individualism" and the approach of a new "organic era*J bonders whether the reformer achieved by the famous producer Stanislavsky in the Soviet Theatre jj ■ did not tend to the suppression of egocentrism very characteris¬ tic of the Russian artists before the Revolution. Difficulty of.organizeing balls which represented the chief, and later the only source of income of the Union. The subscriptions of members were paid very inaccurately. Description of the balls. Hessen soon reliquished the duties of the Chairman of the Union. ,fter his departure chairmen constantly changed, the financial position became precarious, quarrels degenerating into battles took place during the meetings, and on repeated demands from the part of the Union he resumed his chairmanship and worked at the Union until his departure to Paris, i.e. even under Hitler's regime when all the organizations had to adapt themselves to the "Aryan" paragraph. But towards this time the number of the members of the Union was unsignificant.

The rapid increase in the numbers of various Russian organisation brought about a great invonvenience# livery organization applied independently from the rest to the authorities trying to influence their policy towards the refu- ». I ge,.s and the Soviet Government. This resulted in a certain impatience among the German officials. The less influential! ?) organisation was "The Russian delegation in Germany" which had right to issue pa sports to refugees and perform some consular iunctions# It was headed by Bo tkine# The second drawback of the great number of Russian organizations was the difficulty of organizing balls* because every organization gave balls; and in order to keep the public Interested intervals between the balls were necessary. Co¬ ordination was badly needed* two unions were forced 1) composed of eleven organizations the 2) of 14. They could be briefly characterized as 1) with restauration tendencies 2) denying the return to the past# The first was "Aryan" in composition, the other chiefly Jewish. . >oth the Unions sent their representatives to the "Central Organ" which included also the Chairman of "The Russian Delegation in Germany", otkine and a representative cue Red Cross. The "Central 0-y.gan" was the centre of mutual hatred and various intrigues# The Quarrels were caused by the differences of the attitudes towards Soviet Russia and towards the German representative at the Hansen Office, Dr. cchlesinger, who had also a post at the Foreign Department# Dr. Schlesinger was very t ctive on behalf of the refugees and very willing to help theBif it is to hdu that the Society of 1916 owes the creation of the Hansen Helm for homeless refugees. But at the same time Schiesinger was an eager executor of the Rapallo treaty and often went to the U.S.SR# in order to smoothe down various difficulties# The reactionary Emigre organizations could not forgive him this combination of two posts, and a great number of den*nciation-letters ware sent to Geneva# Thds state of

affairs ended in a supaon from the Ministry of the Interiors asking the representatives of the Russian organizations to the office of the Kinistry, where the matter was discussed end Schlesinger kept both his posts. . Relates the endeavours of the anti-Soviet German political personalities to attain a rapprochement with England through the medi m of an English publicist, who was one of Hessen's friends. These endeavours completely f ilea* As regards Gclile singer he did not talc© an,/ part in this incident; his activity on behalf of the refugees though due to his ambition was very useful to Russians, nevertheless the emigres suspected him of "selling them to I oscow" and in spite of all the arguments 17that nobody wished to buy them" saw the "hand of : oscow" everywhere. This nhand of oscoy/" soon bee me a mania even with very cultivated refugees* Owing to constant disagreements within it the "Central Organ" soon faded away into non-existense. A new move towards the unification of the refuge s was given by the creation of the "Day of Bussian Culture" celebrated yearly on the day of Puchkine's birthday (6th of June-* This feast used to bo organized Jointly by all Russian erairr£ org nizations, .Then owinf to Staff promotion Schlesinger rojJntjuished his post and was replaced by r. Stsbbe an atte mpt was made to organize a Russian advisory Committee f eirath), This attempt brought about a renewal of intrigues and quarrels among the Russians* No agreement could be reached, and roon afterwards owing to Germany leaving the League of Nations Dr. Stabbe himself had to resign. Finally un er the Hi tier1s regime 22 ^migr£ organizations were united under the "National" banner; they %?ere headed by Botkine and their activity was limited sending greetings to Hitler; as regards the attitude of the new regime towards this last Union, Botkine was not permitted to return to Germany which he Sad left for a short visit to Paris#

It » i»ll fee f air "to ndd th* t "the tendency "to divide into separate groups was common not only to the right wing emigration, but that it was equally shared by the left parties. Social Demo¬ crats who already in Russia shrunk from mixing with people holding opinions different from their own, no*v grew still more jealous of their"class conciousness". The tendency tc divide reached its -culminating point with the arrival in the autumn of • 1922 of the expelled professors, who immediately opposed them¬ selves, as a group, to the rest of the emigration* This group, however, left a vivid trace in the cultural life of the Russian emigration. Headed by Prof# V#I# Jassinsky {rives a characteristic of Prof. Jassinslcy) the group 0± the expelled professors organised "The ivussiitn Scientific Institute*^ Gf# Ooldenweif er's report. I#K.) Funds were provided directly and inderectly y the German Government. The Scientific Institute in ::::erixn was very similar to other Russian educational institutions in the emigration as for instance "he Russian University in Prague. The programme of the Russian University in Prague could not of course meet the requirements of a systematic University Course. Juridical science predominated; this was due to the outstanding ■ number of Jurists among .he emirrd intellectuals. The Law Faculty stuck to the old methods of instruction hoping for the fall of the Sovient Government. The result wes that 4 years later when the first group of students finished their course, their knowledge had no practical value. The students resented this loss of four years and "rebelled" against the "fathers". This "rebellion" was strengthened by hard material conditions and the young generation decided to /elk its own way. This way, was that of "practicism and acute nationalism^practicism meaning economic security) The story of the Russian Institute in Berlin was very similar to that of the Prague University

With the only difference - in favour of the Berlin Institute - that the students of the latter did not have time to complete their course at the Berlin Institute. Moreover, whilst the students of the Prague University were loth to leave it in order to keep their scholarships (granted by the Czechoslo- v .:£ Government) as 1 rig as possible, the students of the Berlin Institute were bound by nothing, and dispersed after the deflation. The Institute was turned into a scientific institution for the study of the present day Russia. Under tiio |{i txer rdgi;,ic it w s fi.* st "cleansed,r of the non-"Aryan" element, then the cleansing was repeated among the remaining "Aryans" and finally the Institute was closed. All this was as usually accompanied by intrigues, denunciations, etc. Describes the death f Prof. Jassinsky, founder of the Insititute. Follows s description of the productions of nussian plays and operas by Germans. liotes inacuracies. Lesonbes Kussian <5migr<5 productions, Russian companies on tour in Berlin.

IV. The Publishing Firm "SI, VP" (The :'ord) The Firm "Slovo" absorbed the whole of Hessen*s time. Persons! rela tions with the Ullsteins were perfect# The firm Ullstein was occupied ?;ith the cormiiercial part of the work; and Hessen with the publishing work. The programme of the "Slovo" was very varied. It published Russian classics, Russian modern writers, etc. On Hessen*s initiative the firm also started the publishing of the periodical "The rchives of the Russian Revolution", the object of which was to publish all the available documents on the Russian devolution, "The .Archives of the Russian Revolution" had a great success and provoked many imitations. "Glovo" developed very quickly. The best sellers were the Russian classics, especially Puchkine. Among the modern authors great success had Aldanov and irine (follows a characteristic of Sirine as a personality and as a writer. Considers Sirine1s work as very talented and original). Books were published in the old spelling, though Hessen tried to suggest that the new spelling would be more convenient as regards the possibility of sending books to the U»S#S.R# But his collaborators strongly objected. The success of "Slovo" gave raise to the creation of a series of competing Russian publishing firms. The most successful and the most important of the competitors was .Gorki's protog^, Grjebine, who concluded an agreement with the Soviet Government which took the engagement to buy 1,000 copies of every new book published b him. But misunderstanding soon arose between the two pa rtners of the contract, and Grjebine was ruined. In view of the constantly increasing number of new publishing firms "Slovo", again together with the Ullstein firm,formed a Limited Company for the sale of its books; which was called "Logos" Describes the effects of the inflation on business and daily life.

Owing to the inflation most of the Russian publishing firms had to close. Describes the conditions of the Russian writers in the emigration, who generally depended for their life and the publishing of their books on philantropy• "The Kul" (The i.teer) Hessen was doubtful whether the creation of a Russian emigre paper in Berlin would be useful. He was prompted to start publishing the newspaper "Rul" by Ms friend A.Kaminka, who in addition to his assurance as to the usefulness of such an enterprise was desirous to restore his friend Nabokov to active life. Nabokov after the liquidation of the Crimean Government, of which he had been a .member,, was living in London, where together with :ilioukov,he was engaged in the publishing of the journal "hew Russia". Kaminka and Hessen summoned him form London in order to take part in their newspaper. A new agreement was concluded with the Ullstein firm, which were very enthusiastic for the new project. (5th Nov. 1920) Hessen succe ded easily in gathering the necessary funds (18,000 According to this agreement the Ullstein firm put at the disposal of the new paper its premises and its information organization. Brief description of the conditions of publishing newspapers in Germany at that time, and the part played by the press in the German life (this is not very clear I.K.) The first day of the appearance of "The Rul" was the day of the Wrangel's disaster, and the articles the type of which was already set had to be altered. The first number of "The Rul" expres ed the hope that the strug le with the Bolsheviks will nevertheless lead to a victorious end. Brief account of the evacuation of Ahe Frangel's Army from the Crimea.

The reaction of the emigration to the^ rangel1s disaster were the endeavours to form the 11 National Coramittee n which was to be composed of persons belonging to different political parties and having sufficient authority to "defend the international interests of Russia". A partisan of such a committee was P•Milioukov. On the other hand on the initiative of A. ;Gouchkov a Council of the former embers of the Duma and of the State Council was organized. Whilst fc&MBBXdiscussions were going on in both the "National Committee" • nd the "Council",it became clear that the most important problem was thu question of providing food for Go thousand evacuated white soldiers. Emigration was divided. Comparison with the emigration of the Tsarist regime. In "The Rul" Hessen pointed out the necessity of remembering that the conduct of the £migr<*s will be judged in Russia. Polemics of"fhe Rul" with the "Derni&res Nouvelles" Extract from the article by Nabokov addressed to ilioukov and entitled to our *Friend the Opponent". Difficulty of the position of an &sigr£ paper of hat time: on ont hand the paper had to spare the susceptibilities of the Russians who had fought in the iVhite ,rmyt on the other hand the publishers could not help recognizing the fct that a further fight with the USSR, hac become impossible. Hessen's view on the Revolution in general which he thinks to be a phenomenon beyond control; and the difficulty of finding a new political paltform in the emigration. The most urgent task was to study the processes stirred up b the Revolution. I'he difficulty was the absence of any reliable information from Russia. Description of enns of getting this information, private letters, rumours, etc.

In HessenVs opinion "The Rul" succeeded very often to provide its readers rath fairly.reliable information about Russia. Brief impression of the events of that time. Complaint; of the Soviet Representative in Berlin to the German " inistry due to an article in "The Rul"..The unoficial German attitude still re ained friendly towards H ssen's paper in spite of the official remarks made to Heseen* A process started by the Soviet Ambassedor was happily liquidated thanks to the inter¬ ference of Dr. Schlesinger and the amnesty for political offences Vagueness of the daigr£ press and its symbolic language. Different kinds of abuses practised by several emigrants, i.e. false information on people lost during the Civil War to their relations and promises to find them for a certain fee, Zemgor in the hands of the members of one of the Russian political parties, the s. - R.(Socialists Revolutionaries) The atmosphere in Prague - that of people living on philantropy and confined in their narrow interests. Zemgor*s attempts to sue "The Kuln for libel; but the matter did not come to the courts. In addition to law suits, and attacks in the press the publishers of "The Bui" also became the object of hooliganism on the part of both Germans and Russian ^rnigrds. However the incidents which occurred were not serious. The first one was due to an article published in "The Rul" on the division of the Russian Orthodox Church in the emigration. The division of the Russian £mirr£ church was due to the problem whether the emigre^ church was still to regain under the jurisdiction of the I oscow Patriarch (appointed during the revolution; there had been no Patriarch in Russia since Peter the Great, the Church was governed by the Synod) or to become autonomous, T- e question bee me more acute with the death of the Patriarch. The first to rebel against oscow was itropolite Antonius (reactionary un er the Tsar Regime). His example was

followed by < itropolite Julogius who went over to tho jurisdiction of the Greek Patriarch. The church which remained faithful to Joscow {called in Berlin the G.: ,U. Church) retai¬ ned only 10 - 20 members, and is now uruler the jurisdiction of the Lithuanian r itropolite Ulepherius. nd lastly there was in erlin the "Living Church" hich received from the Soviet embassy all the belo rings of the Russian Embassy Church in -erlin. Relates the murder of Nabokov, Tabokov was replaced by G.A, Landau, In spite of all these unfavourable circumstances "The Rul had a g? eat success, its circulation amointed to coo re than 20,000 copies, which went to all the parts of the world. Its financial suec9s also seemed to be very rtaisfactory, so that the Ullstein firm decided to change the contract, in order to heighten its share in the profits and to prolong? the duration of the contract. It was prolonged to 1940. But practically "The Rul" was doomed at the moment of the signature of the new contract. After the deflation 1923 "The Rul" be an to publish an illustrated annex "Our orld" (Hash ir) living infor¬ mation on the jKussian emigration. There was. also a project to start publishing a Year Book of "The Bui" which could five a comprehensive account of the Emigre life. uestionneires were rent to this effect and many answers received, a few oi these answers are still in Hes: en*s possession; the rest had been sent to Prague to . Tlezdelski who wrote a largo . 5 which he sen® to lies sen. The Year Hook however w,.s not published. After the deflation the number of Russians in Berlin rapidly decreased, those who remained became entirely absorbed in the strugrle for life and lost their interest i?jt Russia; this interest remained, however, the chief concern of the paper. The consequence was thatthe sale of the paper became less successful.

The Ullstein firm soon became aware of that as well as of the fact that the omigr^s had no chance to play any part in the development of the new Russia, The contract was cancelled and the publishers of "The Rul" received 50 thousand RM. as a compensation. Two offers to buy the paper were made to the publishers and were both rejected. After vain endeavours to find the necessary funds for the continuation of the paper it had to be liquidated. Taking in consideration the events which then followed Hessen thinks that "The Rul" was liquidated at the rirht time. Reports the opiniors of the Bolsheviks on"The Rul", which show that the Bolsheviks considered it to be an influential paper. Emigre quarrels accusing one another of being subsidized by different Governments. Rumours of the Soviet Government wishing to make peace with the emigration. Arrival to erlin of the Soviet emissary N#D. Sokolov asking £migr6s to return in order to support the "right course1" which was beginning in Russia. Hessen published an article in,f¥he Rul" in w ich he pointed out that Sokolov came not to rec 11 the whole of the emigration but only in order to ehose those who suited the Soviet regime. Sokolov*s propaganda did not remain without response and many of the emigres •ent over to the Soviets as /I. Tolstoi, A. Drozdov, a collaborator of "The Rul" Roman Gul and several others, ^he question arose of excluding them from the dmigrd professional Unions, but they did not wish to leave the Unions desirous to bring the matter before the Courts and make the discussion of the points of vie-: public. This however did not succeed. The saddest fact was that Sokolovfs propaganda

. had a great success among the young Russian draigrds. Their attitude suggested that the old dmigrd leaders had nothing to offer them. Sensational public affirmation of one of the expelled professors ...V. Peshechonov who cor side ed that the Soviet "have taken the responsibility of reconstructjng the authority of the State" provoked fierce controversy, meetings and polemics. Describes a meeting devoted to the discussion of the subject. The discussion only proved that the dmigrds were uncertain as to their position towards Soviet Russia and were in a disordered state of mind. Hessen thinks that if the Bolsheviks would have taken part in all these controversies the matter would have becom; more clear, but the Bolsheviks kept aloof from all discussions and the --migrds had to conduct them alone. As to the ri/ ht wing emigration they were still praying for the Tsar's health and nourishing restauration dreams. Characteristic of the new kind of refugees who had left Russia legally thanks to their relation with some of the Soviet officialstend whose attitude towards the older dmigrds was that of slight contempt. Impression produced on Hessen by these newly arrived people, 'inhere was no common language with them. V.Y. Schulgine and his book on his impressions in Russia where ho secretly went in order to find his lost son. As it was proved later Schulgine1s expedition was organized fey the Soviet Government. He affirmed in his book that the Volgshevists were only "a tool in the hands of the /hite thought". This scandal provoked no special reaction among the dmigrds. The general impression of the emigration engaged in quarrels and intrigues was: "cherches I'argentV Practice of the oviet Government to arrest foreigners in order to exchange them later against Soviet agents arrested in different countries.

essay:div.essay:p: TWENTY YEARS OF RUSSIAN EMIGRATION. W7 -:f: s. yy\Ko&scN, '9 37. Ihe beginning of Russian emigration as a mass movement are linked with the Bolshevik Revolution in November 1917 and the issue of the Civil War that • >iO Yia.2. ^ Wa/uvvw->o-A" i followed. In the interim period of the g■i■muhjfrlgime, after the collapse of theVMonarchy in P»linimij 1917, there werefSolated individuals who preferred voluntary exile abroad to life in democratic Russia under changed conditions, but it was only after the victory of Bolshevism that emigration assumed a mass character. In contrast to the easy victory of the National Socialists in Germany, to lvhom the Government was handed without a struggle, the Bolsheviks in their seizure of power came up against a tough and obstinate resistance on the part of broad circles of the Russian population. Ihis resistance had both an active and a passive character , and took the form of armed struggle, boycott, refusal of co-operation, attempts on the lives of Soviet leaders, etc., but it was powerless to hinder the final victory of the Bolsheviks. The slow strengthening and consolidation of Soviet power in the centre of the former Russian Empire, and the first steps towards the carrying out of the Communist Programme, were accompanied at the same time by a definite process of displacement of certain oooio-1 population groups from the centre of Russia to the anti-Bolshevik periphery. Individually and in groups they fled - former Russian officers, student youth, men of military age - from Red Russia, ano. trickled first towards the South, the Don Territory, where they joined the anti-Bolshevik Volunteer iy then in process of formation. They were followed by the ideologists of the "White" movement. The street combats of those November days in Petrograd and Moscow were to be followed by the struggles

of the anti-Bolshevik "White" troops who for years tried from every side to sexze the territory in Central Russia oooupiod by the Soviet Government. In the South the anti-revolutionary forces operated from the Don province, the Caucasus, the Ukraine and the Crimea. Archangel on the White Sea was the seat of the anti- Bolshevik Northern Government. The Baltic Provinces and White Russia formed the Western theatre of war and the troops, drawn from the moat varied national and political bodies, fought in the Volga and Ural territories and in East and West Siberia. The flight from the land of the Soviets, however, was not limited to the military and the fighting youth. The bourgeoisie, the nobility, professional men, former officials, middle clas¥e^rtgacB^fsin pmblie and^aecondary schools, etc., sought in the Ukraine, in Siberia and in other territories not under Soviet power, to free themselves from the Soviet regime of force. The frozen waters of the Gulf of Finland made flight from Petrograd possible for those who dared not brave the forests of the Russo-Finnish border. The German occupation of the Baltic and Poland seemed for a time to offer a further means of flight from the Red Terror. After the conclusion of the Peace of Brest-Litovsk, and the resumption of diplomatic relations between Germany and Russia, "Zentroplenbezh", a central »w JVl o oc? W organisation for the repatriation of refugees and war prisoners, was founded!/ Hi <IM J And although by refugees were ^chiefly understood those Russian subjects who during the War had fled or been deported from the territories occupied by the Germans into the centre of Russia, from now on many of those whose birthplaces were in these territories sought to attach themselves to the train of returning wanderers. Russian emigration, therefore, in its first stage, took place exclusively on Russian soil. It was caused on the one hand by ideological motives and class

interests, on the other by the terrific pressure exerted by the Soviet Government and Communist Party on the whole bourgeois and anti-communist elements, as well as by the terror which had now become a permanent phenomenon. The abandonment of their places of residence (though not yet of the homeland itself!) resulted partly through flight into the iietricts occupied by the anti-bolshevik forces, partly through emigration into the parts of the former Russian Empire occupied by the Germans and later become independent, the choice of a place of refuge being frequently dicteted by purd y fortuitous circumstances, The actual exodus 01 the Russians to foreign countries, into the territories 01 those Powers allied to Russia in the Great War, of neutrals, of the new states, as well as of former enemies, first began after^the defeat of the anti-revolutionary armies and the final victory of Bolshevism in the Civil War. The Russian White Armies, partly supported in their struggle against Communist Moscow by the Allied Powers, had gradually to evacuate the territories held by them, and were finally forced by the triumphant progress of the Red Army to abandon altogether their native soil. Ihis tragic exodus, unexampled in its extent, took place in separate waves, through the collapse of the successive anti-bolshevik fronts. And the Russian military on their sad journey were accompanied by thousands of refugees from the midst of the civil population. From the Baltic pgov inoes / and the Ukraine, at first occupied by the Germans, but evacuated by them after the Armistice* thousands at the end of 1918 and the beginning of 1919 fled to the West to escape the oncoming Bolsheviks. A large number of the<0jr Russian citizens, who for the most part escaped into Germany, were, however,of German Baltic origin. The Victory of the Red Army over the fellow combatants of General yudeni^ch before the gates of Petersburg in October

1919 forced many to seek shelter and safety in Finland and the Baltic States, vh ich in the meantime had attained independence. The evacuation of Archangel and ths whole of the Northern territory in February 1920 increased still further the number of Russian refugees. After the collapse of Kolchak's army in Decenber 1919 and the gradual occupation of Siberia b- the Bolsheviks (Vladivostok in 1922 was the last to fall into their hands) the Russian military, officials and bourgeoisie fled to the East - to China, Manchuria and Japan. Shanghai and Harbin became the principal centres of this section of the Emigration. Ihe first crowds of Russian refugees arrived in Constantinople in the spring of 1919, after Odessa had been cleared by the French troops. The failures of General Denikin in the South of Russia brought a year later a new and powerful stream of Russian emigrants to the Turkish capital. But it was not until November 1920 that Turkey experienced a real Russian invasion, when, after the surrender of General Wrangel, about 1^5,000 Russians, of whom one-third were civilians, were evacuated on 126 ships from the Crimea, first to Constantinople and thence distributed to Gallipoli, to the Island of Lemnos, to Jugoslavia, Greece, Bulgaria and North Africa. Ihe struggle of the troops of Balachowich operating in White Russia ended in VVmv December 1920 with 1a* internment in Poland. And finally a special group of refugees from the time of the Civil War was formed by the Russian Jews, victims of the numerous bloody pogroms in South Russia, who fled in large numbers to Poland and Rumania. In the years 1918-22 was thus crystallised the nucleus of the Russian emigration which even then ran into seven figures. Ihe emigrants came from every part of the Russian Empire. They belonged to all classes of Russian Society. The vast majority, however, arrived in foreign lands almost entirely penniless, and with no possibility of any sort of economic support from the homeland. On the other hand the means at

the disposal of the various relief organisations were insufficient to ameliorate their condition. 3^A- \/Even after the close of the Civil War and the end of the period of so-called i/ifar Communism, emigration by no means ceased. It assumed, however, and has retained to this day a considerably altered character. Although its proportions still remained considerable it no longer took place in the foim of a oompact, simul¬ taneous mass movement, but now, through the more or less carefully guarded frontiers thousands of refugees, either alone or in small family units or groups of friends, sought to escape the threat of destruction by hunger and privation. In spite of physical dangers lurking in such secret flights, as we^l as often great spiritual conflict, they left their homeland, gave up homes often occupied for generations, broke bonds of family and friendship. Political and religious persecution, economic pressure, deprivation of the elementary rights of citizenship including the right to educate their children, the class war stirred up jwa ooimfopy town by the Communist Party against the bourgeois, forced thousands of Russian citizens to take this step into the unknown. It was a hundred per cent gamble. The slake was life itself. And yet these.Russians preferred an end with terrors to a Terror without end. Outcast, they had, to quote the famous Communist Manifesto, nothing to lose but their chains. And in actual fact a number of inmates of Soviet prisons succeeded in escaping from them and joining the emigration. The twenties brought a new phenomenon - the exiles. In contrast to tte former strictly barred frontiers of Soviet Russia, to crostf which was illegal and higjily punishable, the Soviet Government now themselves exiled from the country such elements as were not prepared to accommodate themselves unconditionally to the new spirit in Bolshevik Russia, and whose attitude was condemned as not correspondiig

to the Marxist view of the world. Among these exiles were famous Russian scholars, philosophers, historians, n&tur© scientists, etc., besides authors, journalists, social and co-operative workers, politicians, social democrats, members of democratic groups. Most of them came first to Berlin and spread afterwards to the most varied countries. A curious fact about these exiles is that they, in spite of their^public activities, kept their Soviet passports even in exile, a fact which applies to some of them at the present day, and that therefore, although emigrants, they must still be regarded as Soviet citizens. A special place among the emigrants is helAby the so called "Ne-Vozvrashchentsy" o Vv<w ................. lormer Communists, members of ag^neie-a representing the Soviets abroad, Soviet employees, specialists, scholars sent to other countries, people, therefore, from the Bolshevik camp, who, for various reasons - self protection, or change of political opinions — refused to obey the recall to Russia and preferred to remain abroad and join the emigration. At first the emigrants established themselves pri ncipally in those countries nearest to Russia. In the course of time, however, they spread themselves over all Continents and there is today hardly a state, hardly a political and economic centre, where they are not represented. After the first exodus-peraod - planless and defined mainly by chance - the Russian emigrant masses established themselves in certain countries, guided thither by the assistance rendered by the various Governments and philanthropic organisations, by material motives, questions of kinship, mental and racial affinity, political sympathies etc. So were formed the greatest European gathering points of Rueeian Emigration. i„ Pari3j Prague> Berlinj Belgradej gofta> etc> But the importance of these points varied according to changes in the general condition of the country in question. This continual fluctuation of emigration was

a v*> \~»Wi'cAs- VJ tA-C influenced by a number of causes, ohiofly hiswevey, by variations in the cost of living index in individual lands. In the years 1919-24, for instance, Berlin, thanks to the German inflation which greatly reduced the cost of living and aJb out¬ produced a considerable^demand fiosr workers, became the leading centre of Russian emigration, of the Russian press, of book production, cultural institutions and many larger or smaller commercial undertakings. After the stabilisation of the Mark, however, in 1924, resulting in a sudden sharp rise in prices and progressive increase in unemployment, a number of the Russian immigrants found it economically impossible to remain longer in the country, and wandered away to other lands - to Prance, where living had cheapened, to Czechoslovakia, or to the Eastern border countries. Ever increasing economic pressure in the majority of European countries and the consequent impossibility of permanently housing large masses z> of Russian immigrants, also led to the formation of various projects, only partially carried out, for the settlement of refugees in the South American countries. It can be seen from the following examples how on their side political events influenced the destiny of the emigrants. After the Russo-Turkish treaty concluded in 19 , the Angora Government pledged itself to receive no further Russian refugees, and those already in Turkey were obliged to choose between adopting National Socialist Turkish nationality or leaving the country. In the same way the/revolution in Germany brought great changes into the structure of the^emigrant colony in the country, which, through the departure of the Jews and in spite of the admission of Russian fascist elements, was still further diminished. The conclusion of the Franco-Russian pact and the approach of Czechoslovakia to Soviet Russia also had a great effect on the lives of the emigrants. A further characteristic of the Russian Emigration is the special social, political and spiritual phisiognomy of the different centres. The relatively

small Russian colony in London, for example, apart from certain members of the Imperial Family and the Russian arist6cracy, consists mainly of military and commercial circles, especially from North Russia and Siberia, which, with assistance from England, were brought over after the Civil War. On the other hand, in Prague Russian iaraigration is characterised by relatively deep strata of the academic intelligentsia - -university professors and students of democratic stamp - v/hich had grouped themselves for the most part round the Zem-Gor Organisation. Jugoslavia and Bulgaria again were places of refuge chiefly of the Russian military, and as a consequence the male element strongly predominates. South Germany, Munich and Coburg in particular, received the reactionary and monarchistic Russian circles, who crowded round Grand Duke Cyril as the pretender to the Russian Throne. The rallying point, however, of all streams of emigration, and the "Capital" of the refugees, is undoubtedly Paris, where every kind of political emigration group, from the extreme right and the Cossack Unions, through the repub¬ lican democrats to the Menshevik (Social Sjemocrat^) and social revolutionary parties, are represented. Ihe anmigrants in France also possess the greatest number of Russian professional associations,many cultural and educational institu¬ tions and include^ all social classes, with large numbers of the Russian town and land proletariat, (it is here that the regrouping process among Russian emigrants has been most complete) together with independent farmers and the greater part of the still existing Russian bourgeoisie. What were the political aims of the Russian emigrants? There was at first a part of the anti-Bolshevik military who, as emigrants, even from a foreign country and on foreign soil, wished to continue active warfare against Soviet Rus¬ sia. However, with the increased stabilisation of the Soviet Regime, the ever

growing desire of the different foreign states again to make an approach to Russia, and the gradual de jure recognition of the Soviet Government, this hope of the emigrants proved to be deceptive. Under pressure from Prance General Wrangel in 1921 was obliged, much against his will, to disband the army he had brought into Turkey. Still other methods of combating Bolshevism were tried - attempts by conspiracy to get into touch with anti-revolutionary circles inside Soviet Russia, smuggling of anti-communist literature over the Russian border, influencing of public opinion abroad, etc. But the adoption of these methods, to some extent taken over from the old, pre-revolutionary anti-Czarist emigrants, was considerably hindered by internal disunity in the camp itself. For from the beginning the emigration had from the political aspect displayed in its moods, interests, programmes and orientations, a truly kaleidoscopic colour scheme. Even in the fundamental question of their attitude towards the Soviet Government in the event of Russia's again becoming involved in a war, the views of the emigrants diverged, and still today diverge, very widely. While certain groups would be ready to support the Soviet Government as might be possible in the event of a war threat to their Fatherland, others would be prepared to throw in their lot even with the enemies of their country if it seemed likely to lead to the overthrow of the hated rulers in Moscow. Again, in their programmes as to a future form of government for a Russia liberated from Communism - monarchy, republic, retention of the Soviets, etc - the ideas of the different groups vary enormously. Repeated attempts, the last in 1926, to unify all anti-bolshevik forces dn one broad foundation, proved impos¬ sible to carry out. The element of dissension is, in fact, a general characteristic 1 "the emigrants, a community living under unnatural conditions, divided in any case against itself, and furthermore exposed to the varied influences of the most heterogeneous surroundings. Even the exiled Russian Church has not escaped a

similar disruption, and for a time suffered a bitter internal struggle. As active warfare became more and more impossible, and the idea of inter¬ vention had to be abandoned, and as the collapse of the Soviet regime, regarded as inevitable and daily expected, was still postponed, the hope of return to the homeland faded further and xurther into the distance. And although even today many emigrants are psychologically in the position of railway passengers sitting on their trunks and waiting for the signal to depart, yet for the greater number it has been necessary to look round for some place to "dig themselves in". The struggle for the bare necessities of lue more and more absorbed the energies of the emigrants and their situation became the more difficult as the funds at the disposal of the Governments and philanthropic organisations who had hitherto supported them were gradually exhausted. Ihe efforts of Fritjof Nansen to vp»\ VWc. r*A~T• V\- ky VV/u- Sw repatriate a number of the Russians were, on the other hand, wrecked^on the reluctance of the emigrants themselves, and their mistrust of the Bolshevik system. | Only a small number, about ^>}^00 soldiers of the ./range 1 army, had already, through France's mediation, declared themselves ready to return to Russia. Ihe broad mas- ses of the emigrants made no response to the invitation of the Soviet Government, available till to apply for a Soviet passport at the nearest consulate. And at the end of this period the Moscow Government finally deprived the emigrants of their civic rights prsmottnaad ittnlf to Ac ifrac an m.r. After this it was only by personal amnesty that individual citizens were granted permission to return to their home land. The high figures of alleged returned refugees given in Soviet statistics are to be explained by the fact that the crowds of returnirg prisoners of war areValso included. The distribution and settlement of the refugees was chiefly determined in

the beginning by the already mentioned causes of geographical proximity, chance conditions, and the degree of importance with reference to the future ascribed by individual states to the temporary sheltering of the emigrants. Later, however, questions of the labour market and the existing economic situationbecame decisive factors regulating the futther development of the Emigration, /ft proved nowhere really possible to carry out a systematic settlement of the emigrants owing to the lack of necessary funds, increasing rejection in certain countries of foreign immigration, acuteness of the world economic crisis and universal unemployment. The Russian emigrants1 struggle for existence was further intensified by the lack of opportunity afforded them to practise their former professions in countries whose peoples themselves were^suffering from the results of the world war. This meant in most cases a difficult process of re-grouping, which was all the more painful that a great percentage of the emigrants were highly educated people, formerly in comfortable circumstances, and who now had in many cases to turn their hands to manual labour, Nevertheless, in spite of unwonted physical strain and the spiritual distress consequent upon necessary adaptation to a wholly new manner of life, the Russian emigrants went to work, when work offered itself, as Dr. Nansen testifies "with a splendid and resolute effort", and showed "a determination and enterprise which is beyond all praise." That the burden of suffering often proved too much for the powers of resistance, weakened by struggle and privation, of these uprooted people, is proved by the large number of suicides among them. In the larger centres, with a view to self help and protection of their special interests, a number of associations were formed in which were banded to-

V'"s; ■" i gether the members of various professions such as scientists, doctors, engineers, lawyers, authors, actors, chauffeurs, etc. The membership of these associations was increased by the adherence of those Russians who, although having now acquired other nationalities, yet did not wish to sever their connection with the groups ' ■ ——— t ,n t... of emigrants to which they had belonged. Other emigrant associations, whose members grouped themselves according to common local origin, social class, educational institution#, regiments in the Czarist army, etc., followed the same aims of economic and legal self protection, together with othersof a cultural nature, as the professional societies, for mutual consultation and coordination of their activities several congresses and conferences have been held ams&g cmi^rcmU, not only 01 political and academic organisations tjhcraeolvcu but also inoIudin~ representatives of similar professional associations from the various countries over which the emigrants are scattered. A further problem manifesting itself in the cultural realm, was thestrugJLP against threatened denationalisation of Young Russia, growing up in foreign lands, and for the conservation and further development of Russian national cultural values. The obvious way to this end was in the larger centres the early foundation of schools, in which Russian children could be educated according to the pre-revolutionary programme in their mother tongue, and in accordance with the Russian spirit and g o* v»co V." <1 v» aX- tradition. The same object was served by the higher »eh-oe 1 e'^for^young people A instituted in different places such as the Russian Scientific Institute in Berlin, the legal faculties in Prague and Harbin, the Theological Institute in Paris, and n .-r-j others. Yet as the years passed the fulfilment of this task presented ever greater difficulties. The number of Russian children gradually increased who had never

seen their fatherland, who knew it only hearsay, and for whom even the Russian language provided no natural and familiar idiom. The child's dislike of appearing different from his playfellows through any national peculiarities or characteris¬ tics added to the difficulties. Various considerations often of a practical nature tended to urge Russian youth to accommodate itself to its surroundings, to adopt foreign customs and cultural values, and sometimes even to merge itself completely in the sheltering nation. The financial support of these Russian educational institutions was another great problem. Although, however, a number of them have had to be closed, there are still a good many Russian schools scattered over the countries of the dispersion which, because of the lavishness of their programme and the high level of instruction, are even attended, as in Prague, by the native born children. A further testimony to the emigrants 1 will to spiritual self preservation and development, creativeness and the fostering of the cultural heritage of past generations, is afforded by the appearance of a number of newspapers, periodicals, books etc. The circulation, in some cases very large, reached its highest figures in the years 1921-25. It has since declined, but a considerable number of these « ^ VW- X+u zjbJL -AxtA^' Vfc. publications are still being issued, and according to the records/** Prague, the most important centre forVthis literature, in 195^ 10? Russian newspapers appeared, including those of the Russian minorities. The yearly number of Russian aowgpapsro printed abroad ranges between 150 and 200, the total number of titles of such publications registered in the ftrchive# being 1268*- In this effort to maintain their own cultural tradition and to preserve the national individuality, apart from the special cultural, pedagogic and scientific institutions, the Russian Church abroad played an important part. As a religious and intellectual gathering point, it saved the scattered companies of refugees from

complete assimilation to the peoples of other culture and faith. As a confession of faith the special "Day of Russian Culture" has since 19 ^ been solemnly observed every year at the beginning of June in every gathering point, small or great, of the Russian dispersion all over the world. Twenty years long the Russian Emigration has struggled against Bolshevism for a modest place in the sun and the preservation of the national soul. Everywhere today v#e can iind these homeless people - a still foreign but now familiar feature of the living organisms of the nations who shelter them, sharing the labour and trials of their hosts, but seldom admitted by them to the festal board. The lot of a Russian emigrant is generally a wretched one. The refugee who today is refused the permit to work is, on the same day forced to register for military service in case of need, and may perhaps tomorrow have to fight his own Russian brothers in the enemy camp. In the limitation of his right to work and in all his activities he is placed in the same position as all other foreigners, although to them the way back to the homeland remains open. And through lack of a national passport and consequent visa difficulties his freedom of movement is more restricted than theirs. Most tragic of all, however, is the fate of the ageing emigrant, helpless, unable to earn his bread, and deprived of all legal claim to support. The memory of a great Yesterday, the hope of a happier Tomorrow, has given the Russian emigrant courage to face the hardships of Today.
